title.Name: title
title.Value: Orbea Orca Carbon Beauty - Road Bike Check - BikemanforU

description.Name: description
description.Value: http://www.youtube.com/bikemanforu An Orbea Orca, a super lightweight, extremely expensive road bike is hurting but still beautiful. Free Shipping at http://www.bikemanforu.com on bike parts, tires, tools, and cycling accessories. In this road bike video, YouTube's how-to guru of bicycle repair shows us Shimano's top quality Dura Ace componentry and strikingly elegant carbon fiber frame construction, while pointing out the ugly damage that salt does to a bike. This is a really, really nice bike, a really, really expensive bicycle...he got the deluxe version -- full Dura Ace 10 speed (cassette) on the back, two (chainrings) in the front, giving you 20 speeds, with Dura Ace levers, an FSA full-carbon aero handlebar, and Dura Ace brakes. "This Maavic is kinda neat," he notes. "It's a fat-bladed spoke but it's extremely lightweight," noting the sealed hub and presumably titanium lollipop pedals. "It's a very smooth riding machine," he adds. "Because, again, everything is weight, weight, and more weight."  The damage is noticeable. "We rinsed it off as best we can. We're gonna shoot, maybe, some Scotch Brite to try to get some of that corrosion off. Relubricate. Readjust up. It's a shame." He points out rust and corrosion underneath the chrome-plated aluminum derailleur and on the crank arm, one of the few steel parts on the bike. "You can see the brown ugly rust down the pipe on that crank," BikemanforU says, observing it's an FSA SLK carbon shell crank. "Salt damage is just deadly on a bicycle. Make sure you rinse off your bicycle. I don't care how expensive it is. You've got to get the salt off." Despite the nautical model name, this Orbea has a severe case of Dune Road-itis, which is the nasty salt water corrosion that infects any bike whose owner dares to ride on the barrier beach off Westhampton Beach, along the Atlantic coast of Long Island's south shore in New York. "The best thing to do," suggests Long Island's top bicycle mechanic, "is just not go through the salt water. Turn around. It's a barrier beach. You go up to it. Oh my goodness look at the water. It's flooded at high tide.. Either that, or check your tides. We're going bikin' not boatin'." Thumbs up if you like what you see. Post comments or video responses. Watch our full playlist of the good, the bad, the weird, the ugly, and the most sublimely beautiful bikes you'll ever see. http://bit.ly/10qbCKL
